en.value: <strong>By saying that we take life for granted, the writer wants to say that:</strong>
en.comp:
Read the passage given below and answer the question that follow:

1. Most of us take life for granted. We know that one day we must die, but usually we picture that day as far in the future. When we are in buoyant health, death is all but unimaginable. We seldom think of it. The days stretch out in an endless vista. So we go about our petty tasks, hardly aware of our listless attitude towards life.

2. The same lethargy, I am afraid, characterizes the use of all our faculties and senses. Only the deaf appreciate hearing, only the blind realize the manifold blessings that lie in sight. Those who have never suffered impairment of sight or hearing seldom make the fullest use of these blessed faculties. Their eyes and ears take in all sights and sounds hazily, without concentration and with little appreciation. It is the same old story of not being grateful for what we have until we lose it, of not being conscious of health until we are ill.

3. I who am blind can give one hint to those who see: Use your eyes as if tomorrow you would be stricken blind. Hear the music of voices, the song of a bird, the mighty strains of an orchestra, as if you would be stricken deaf tomorrow. Touch each object as if tomorrow your tactile sense would fail. Smell the perfume of flowers, taste with relish each morsel, as if tomorrow you could never smell and taste again. 1. Most of us take life for granted. We know that one day we must die, but usually we picture that day as far in the future. When we are in buoyant health, death is all but unimaginable. 2. The same lethargy, I am afraid, characterizes the use of all our faculties and senses. Only the deaf appreciate hearing, only the blind realize the manifold blessings that lie in sight. en.value: <strong>The narrator of this poem is:</strong>
en.comp:
Read the poem given below and answer the question that follow:

Day by day I float my paper boats one by one down the running stream.

In big black letters I write my name on them and the name of the village where I live.

I hope that someone in some strange land will find them and know who I am.

I load my little boats with shiuli flower from our garden, and

hope that these blooms of the dawn will be carried safely to land

In the night I launch my paper boats and look up into the sky and see the

little clouds setting thee white bulging sails.

I know not what playmate of mine in the sky sends them down

the air to race with my boats!

When night comes I bury my face in my arms and dream that my

paper boats float on and on under the midnight stars.

The fairies of sleep are sailing in them, and the lading ins

their baskets full of dreams

The fact that Kalam&#39;s father believed in set patterns can be evinced from the fact that:
en.comp:
Directions: Read the passage given below and answer the question that follows:

1. Kalam says, "I remember my father starting his day at 4 am by reading the namaz before dawn. After the namaz, he used to walk down to a small coconut grove we owned, about 4 miles from our home. He would return, with about a dozen coconuts tied together thrown over his shoulder, and only then would he have his breakfast. This remained his routine even when he was in his late sixties."

2. I have throughout my life tried to emulate my father in my own world of science and technology. I have endeavoured to understand the fundamental truths revealed to me by my father, and feel convinced that there exists a divine power that can lift one up from confusion, misery, melancholy and failure, and guide one to one's true place. And once an individual severs his emotional and physical bondage, he is on the road to freedom, happiness and peace of mind.

3. My father once told me, "In his own time, his own place, in what he really is, and in the stage he has reached-good or bad-every human being is a specific element within the whole of the manifest Divine Being. So why be afraid of difficulties, sufferings and problems? When troubles come, try to understand the relevance of your sufferings. Adversity always presents opportunities for introspection."

4. His answer filled me with a strange energy and enthusiasm: Whenever human beings find themselves alone, as a natural reaction, they start looking for company. Whenever they are in trouble, they look for someone to help them. Whenever they reach an impasse, they look to someone to show them the way out. Every recurrent anguish, longing, and desire finds its own special helper.

options.value: he woke up at four and went to the coconut grove before breakfast for many years&nbsp;
he ate the same food for more than sixty years
he said his prayers every day without fail till the very end
he went to work at the same time every day

en.value: Kalam&#39;s father&rsquo;s definition of suffering filled him with:&nbsp;
en.comp:
Directions: Read the passage given below and answer the question that follows:

1. Kalam says, "I remember my father starting his day at 4 am by reading the namaz before dawn. After the namaz, he used to walk down to a small coconut grove we owned, about 4 miles from our home. He would return, with about a dozen coconuts tied together thrown over his shoulder, and only then would he have his breakfast. This remained his routine even when he was in his late sixties."

2. I have throughout my life tried to emulate my father in my own world of science and technology. I have endeavoured to understand the fundamental truths revealed to me by my father, and feel convinced that there exists a divine power that can lift one up from confusion, misery, melancholy and failure, and guide one to one's true place. And once an individual severs his emotional and physical bondage, he is on the road to freedom, happiness and peace of mind.

3. My father once told me, "In his own time, his own place, in what he really is, and in the stage he has reached-good or bad-every human being is a specific element within the whole of the manifest Divine Being. So why be afraid of difficulties, sufferings and problems? When troubles come, try to understand the relevance of your sufferings. Adversity always presents opportunities for introspection."

4. His answer filled me with a strange energy and enthusiasm: Whenever human beings find themselves alone, as a natural reaction, they start looking for company. Whenever they are in trouble, they look for someone to help them. Whenever they reach an impasse, they look to someone to show them the way out. Every recurrent anguish, longing, and desire finds its own special helper.

en.value: The person who donated her old games to the writer&#39;s children was:
en.comp:
Directions: Read the passage given below and answer the question that follows:

1. I decided to dedicate the month of February to acknowledge my neighbours who had been kind to me. I decided, and I thought of a dozen names right away. I remembered when the owners of our local bookstore let me and my five-year-old son, Henry, in before the store opened and offered to play his favourite soundtrack (Mary Poppins). I recalled when our 14-year-old babysitter dropped off a bag of old board games for our kids to play.

2. By the time I got to July, I had become fairly adept at retrieving memories and identifying people to thank. Among that month's recipients was a chef, Julie, who had cooked at my favourite but now defunct restaurant. I was delighted to receive a note back from her. Julie replied, "I don't think I've ever received such a touching letter before. Out of the blue and incredibly thoughtful. And so needed at a time when I'm struggling professionally. It was one of many responses throughout the year that said something along the lines of, "I'm going through a tough time right now, and this helped."

3. What was I doing when I scrolled through Instagram? More often than not, I was admiring other people's lives-their beach vacations, their chubby babies, and their organized kitchens. Writing thank-you notes on the other hand was an act of noticing and honouring my own life.

4. Part of the magic of what I am calling my "Thank-You Year' was reconnecting with people. I was reminded to acknowledge people at the moment, to smile or say hello, or thanks, or "Here, let me help you with that."

5. Writing the notes wasn't all that time-consuming: Each was two or three sentences long, taking just a few minutes to compose. I focused on the person I was writing to and what I wanted to say, and the words came fairly easily.
